factoid: Pierre made up his mind to obey his monitress implicitly.
Pierre moved toward the sofa that Anna Mikháylovna had indicated.
Anna Mikháylovna disappeared.
The eyes of everyone in the room turned to Pierre with more than curiosity and sympathy.
Everyone in the room whispered to one another while casting significant looks at Pierre with awe and servility.
Pierre received a deference he had never before received.
A strange lady who had been talking to the priests rose and offered Pierre her seat.
An aide‑de‑camp picked up and returned a glove that Pierre had dropped.
The doctors became respectfully silent as Pierre passed by.
The doctors moved to make way for Pierre.
Pierre wished to take another seat so as not to trouble the lady.
Pierre wished to pick up the glove himself.
Pierre wished to pass around the doctors who were not even in his way.
Pierre felt that taking another seat would not do.
Pierre felt that tonight he was obliged to perform some sort of awful rite expected by everyone.
Pierre felt he was bound to accept the services of everyone.
Pierre took the glove in silence from the aide‑de‑camp.
Pierre sat down in the lady’s chair.
Pierre placed his huge hands symmetrically on his knees in the naive attitude of an Egyptian statue.
Pierre decided that all was as it should be.
Pierre decided that to avoid losing his head and doing foolish things he must not act on his own ideas tonight.
Pierre decided that he must yield himself up entirely to the will of those who were guiding him.
Prince Vasíli entered the room with his head erect majestically within two minutes.
Prince Vasíli was wearing a long coat with three stars on his breast.
Prince Vasíli seemed to have grown thinner since the morning.
Prince Vasíli’s eyes seemed larger than usual when he glanced around and noticed Pierre.
Prince Vasíli went up to Pierre, took Pierre’s hand, and drew it downwards as if wishing to ascertain whether it was firmly fixed on.
Prince Vasíli said, “Courage, courage, my friend! He has asked to see you. That is well!” and turned to go.
Pierre thought it necessary to ask “How is…”.
Pierre hesitated, not knowing whether it would be proper to call Prince Vasíli “the count,” yet ashamed to call him “father.”
Prince Vasíli said, “He had another stroke about half an hour ago. Courage, my friend…”.
Pierre’s mind was confused.
The word “stroke” suggested to Pierre a blow from something.
Pierre looked at Prince Vasíli in perplexity.
Pierre later grasped that a stroke was an attack of illness.
Prince Vasíli said something to Lorrain in passing.
Prince Vasíli went through the door on tiptoe.
Prince Vasíli could not walk well on tiptoe.
Prince Vasíli’s whole body jerked at each step.
The eldest princess followed Prince Vasíli.
The priests went in at the door.
The deacons went in at the door.
Some servants went in at the door.
Through that door was heard a noise of things being moved about.
Anna Mikháylovna ran out, still with the same expression, pale but resolute in the discharge of duty, touching Pierre lightly on the arm.
Anna Mikháylovna said, “The divine mercy is inexhaustible! Unction is about to be administered. Come.”
Pierre went in at the door, stepping on the soft carpet.
Pierre noticed that the strange lady followed him in.
Pierre noticed that the aide‑de‑camp followed him in.
Pierre noticed that some of the servants followed him in.
They all followed Pierre in as if there were now no further need for permission to enter that room.
